prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: The world-famous 'great detective', above whose lodgings Miss Susato and I rent our own office and rooms.
Character 2
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 3
Name: Pop Windibank
Description: The proprietor of a pawnbrokery on Baker Street that is regularly patronised by Mr Sholmes. He has a very great sense of responsibility to his clients.
Character 4
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A young pickpocket who we first met during a trial two months ago. She and Iris have become firm friends since.
Character 5
Name: Eggert Benedict → Ashley Graydon
Description: A young English gentleman with an aloof and high-handed manner. He appeared at Windibank's pawnbrokery accusing Gina of stealing his redemption ticket.
Character 6
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 7
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: The infamous London-based prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Further details about the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Nash Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Ringo. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Character 10
Name: Ringo Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Nash. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Music Box Disk
Description: A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. The piece of music, which remains unidentified, is stored on the disk by means of small protrusions. A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. On the reverse side is a note that reads, 'For McGilded'.
Evidence 2
Name: White Cat Photograph → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Box)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat, obtained from Gina while interviewing her in her prison cell. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank, in the form of some hand-written notes on the back of a photograph.
Evidence 3
Name: Gina's Representation Papers
Description: The paperwork signed by Gina to put me in charge of her defence. Showing this to Scotland Yard detectives gains us access to the crime scene.
Evidence 4
Name: White Cat Photograph #2 → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Coat)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat. I feel as though I have another print just like this one... A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. There's what looks like a bloody fingermark on it. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. The blood on it has been identified as Mr Mason's.
Evidence 5
Name: Blood Samples Portfolio
Description: A sample of blood analysed with a special chemical indicator developed by Mr Sholmes. Different people's blood turns different colours.
Evidence 6
Name: Iris's Story Manuscript
Description: A long, unpublished story that Mr Sholmes deposited at the pawnbrokery of the victim, Mr Windibank. It's entitled 'The Hound of the Baskervilles'.
Evidence 7
Name: McGilded Case Notes
Description: Notes collated by Miss Susato about the McGilded case that we worked on two months ago.
Evidence 8
Name: Today's Paper
Description: This morning's paper, purchased by Iris. Gina's case features prominently. This morning's paper, which contains an article about government secrets being leaked to foreign agencies.
Evidence 9
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: A report prepared by the Scotland Yard coroner that confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back. There are no other signs of trauma.
Evidence 10
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the victim found murdered in the storeroom. It shows the single bullet wound in the man's back.
Evidence 11
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of Windibank's pawnbrokery, the scene of the crime. It shows the relative positions of the main shop and the rear storeroom.
Evidence 12
Name: Windibank's Gun
Description: A gun belonging to the victim, Mr Windibank, that Gina was holding when she was found unconscious. There are signs of a single discharge.
Evidence 13
Name: Skulkin Brothers' Gun
Description: A firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired.
Evidence 14
Name: Photograph of Gina
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene a short time before the murder took place.
Evidence 15
Name: Post-Shooting Photograph
Description: A photograph taken automatically by the Red-Handed Recorder showing the scene after the murder had taken place.
Evidence 16
Name: Stereoscope
Description: A fold-up device that allows anybody to enjoy seeing things in three dimensions simply by looking through the eyepieces.
Evidence 17
Name: Sholmes's Pouch
Description: The pouch Mr Sholmes was wearing around his waist at the time of the shooting. One of the glass phials is smashed and there are scorch marks around it.
Evidence 18
Name: The Third Bullet
Description: A projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes.
Evidence 19
Name: Small Music Box
Description: This strange music box only appears to be able to play a single tone. It was deposited at Windibank's two days before the black overcoat.
Evidence 20
Name: Cat-Flapomat
Description: A compact machine for the rapid creation of small flaps in larger doors, to allow cats to come and go freely.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Alright, we did knock a few things over. But we weren't riflin' fer nuffin'!
Person: Nash
Testimony 1
Testimony: It woz when we 'eard the gunshot, see. Made us both jump, an' all that stuff went flyin'.
Person: Ringo
Testimony 2
Testimony: Just before the gunshot, we 'eard a voice yellin' out, 'Gimme that gun!'
Person: Ringo
Testimony 3
Testimony: The bloke wot owned the place was 'oldin' a gun, so 'e should 'ave just fired instead of yellin' at the girl!
Person: Nash
Testimony 4
Testimony: Lummy, it didn't 'alf gimme a fright! We woz thinkin' the shooter'd come out the door and get us next.
Person: Nash
Testimony 5
Testimony: We stuck everyfin' back where we found it and scarpered...straight into 'im in the black.
Person: Ringo
Testimony 6
Testimony: We couldn't 'ave shot the pawnbroker, see! We never even 'ad a chance, did we?
Person: Nash

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Let's analyze the testimonies and evidence for contradictions:

Testimony 3 (Nash): "The bloke wot owned the place was 'oldin' a gun, so 'e should 'ave just fired instead of yellin' at the girl!"

Looking at the evidence about the crime:
- Evidence 9 (Autopsy Report): "A report prepared by the Scotland Yard coroner that confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back. There are no other signs of trauma."
- Evidence 10 (Crime Scene Photograph): Shows the bullet wound in the victim's back.
- Evidence 12 (Windibank's Gun): "A gun belonging to the victim, Mr Windibank, that Gina was holding when she was found unconscious. There are signs of a single discharge."

Now, in Testimony 3, Nash claims that Windibank was holding the gun and should have fired instead of yelling. However, the evidence (Photograph of Gina, etc.) makes it clear that Gina was holding the gun when discovered. Also, Windibank was shot in the back, suggesting he wasn't holding the gun, or at least wasn't in a position to use it.

A stronger contradiction is present between:

Evidence 13 (Skulkin Brothers' Gun): "A firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired." 
Testimony 6 (Nash): "We couldn't 'ave shot the pawnbroker, see! We never even 'ad a chance, did we?"

This is a direct contradiction: The Skulkin brothers' gun was discharged, yet Nash claims they "never even had a chance" to shoot.

Therefore, the answer is:

cot: Testimony 3 by Graydon dismisses the discovery of his blood at the crime scene, casting doubt on the blood evidence. The Blood Samples Portfolio (Evidence 5) provides scientific proof (via Sholmes's chemical indicator) that different people's blood shows up in different colors, directly supporting the claim that Graydon's blood was indeed found at the scene. Thus, his testimony is contradicted by this evidence.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: There's a note on the disk saying, 'For McGilded', but the item belongs to me.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 1
Testimony: The redemption ticket was stolen from me by the accused - that filthy gutterling - on the day in question.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 2
Testimony: I proceeded at once to the shop in order to explain my situation and redeem my article.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 3
Testimony: In the end, of course, the disk was taken by the police.
Person: Graydon
Testimony 4
Testimony: In other words...I had absolutely no reason to break into the shop later that same night.

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot: The testimony "In the end, of course, the disk was taken by the police." implies that Graydon gave up the Music Box Disk to the authorities. However, according to the evidence, the disk had a note on it that said "For McGilded," but Graydon claims in his earlier testimony that the item (the disk) belongs to him. This presents a contradiction, because if the disk was truly his, it would not make sense for it to have a note referring to McGilded instead of Graydon himself. Thus, the item was likely never actually Graydon's property, contradicting his claim of ownership.

Testimony: It was some low-class brickmaker negotiating with McGilded anyway, was it not? I've no relation to the man!
Person: Graydon
Testimony 3
Testimony: Look, all we dun is break into the gaff the other night like wot 'e told us to do!
Person: Nash
Testimony 4
Testimony: If we'd known there woz dodgy gov'ment secrets involved, we wouldn't 'ave touched it!
Person: Ringo
Testimony 5
Testimony: 'Milverton & Skulkin's Milk Run'... Gor, them were the days!
Person: Nash

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot: The contradiction lies between Evidence 1 (Music Box Disk) and Testimony 1 (by Graydon). Graydon claims "the sounds produced by that music box aren't even Morse code!" However, the Music Box Disk, linked to government secrets (as hinted in Evidence 8 and the general context), is suspected to encode such information, and its connection to 'For McGilded' and the espionage plot suggests the opposite: the music box’s sounds are important and are likely in Morse code.

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba

Character 1
Name: Herlock Sholmes

Character 2
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 3
Name: Pop Windibank
Description: The proprietor of a pawnbrokery on Baker Street that is regularly patronised by Mr Sholmes. He has a very great sense of responsibility to his clients.
Character 4
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A young pickpocket who we first met during a trial two months ago. She and Iris have become firm friends since.
Character 5
Name: Eggert Benedict → Ashley Graydon
Description: A young English gentleman with an aloof and high-handed manner. He appeared at Windibank's pawnbrokery accusing Gina of stealing his redemption ticket.
Character 6
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 7
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: The infamous London-based prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Further details about the man are not forthcoming.
Character 9
Name: Nash Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Ringo. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Character 10
Name: Ringo Skulkin
Description: A witness to the event who broke into Windibank's on the night of the murder with his brother and accomplice Nash. He claims to be a 'profeshnal baddie' by trade.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Music Box Disk
Description: A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. The piece of music, which remains unidentified, is stored on the disk by means of small protrusions. A metal disk used to play music in a mechanical music box. On the reverse side is a note that reads, 'For McGilded'.
Evidence 2
Name: White Cat Photograph → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Box)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat, obtained from Gina while interviewing her in her prison cell. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank, in the form of some hand-written notes on the back of a photograph.
Evidence 3
Name: Gina's Representation Papers
Description: The paperwork signed by Gina to put me in charge of her defence. Showing this to Scotland Yard detectives gains us access to the crime scene.
Evidence 4
Name: White Cat Photograph #2 → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Coat)
Description: A photograph depicting a sweet little white cat. I feel as though I have another print just like this one... A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. There's what looks like a bloody fingermark on it. A redemption ticket issued from the pawnbrokery owned by the victim, Mr Windibank. The blood on it has been identified as Mr Mason's.
Evidence 5
Name: Blood Samples Portfolio
Description: A sample of blood analysed with a special chemical indicator developed by Mr Sholmes. Different people's blood turns different colours.
Evidence 6
Name: Iris's Story Manuscript
Description: A long, unpublished story that Mr Sholmes deposited at the pawnbrokery of the victim, Mr Windibank. It's entitled 'The Hound of the Baskervilles'.
Evidence 7
Name: McGilded Case Notes
Description: Notes collated by Miss Susato about the McGilded case that we worked on two months ago.
Evidence 8
Name: Today's Paper
Description: This morning's paper, purchased by Iris. Gina's case features prominently. This morning's paper, which contains an article about government secrets being leaked to foreign agencies.
Evidence 9
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: A report prepared by the Scotland Yard coroner that confirms instant death due to a single bullet wound from the back. There are no other signs of trauma.
Evidence 10
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photograph of the victim found murdered in the storeroom. It shows the single bullet wound in the man's back.
Evidence 11

Description: A plan of Windibank's pawnbrokery, the scene of the crime. It shows the relative positions of the main shop and the rear storeroom.

Evidence 13

Description: A firearm found in the possession of the Skulkin brothers upon their arrest. There are signs that a single round was fired.
Evidence 14

Evidence 15

Evidence 16
Name: Stereoscope
Description: A fold-up device that allows anybody to enjoy seeing things in three dimensions simply by looking through the eyepieces.
Evidence 17
Name: Sholmes's Pouch
Description: The pouch Mr Sholmes was wearing around his waist at the time of the shooting. One of the glass phials is smashed and there are scorch marks around it.
Evidence 18

Description: A projectile we discovered lodged in Mr Sholmes's pouch. It caused one of the phials to explode, injuring Mr Sholmes.
Evidence 19
Name: Small Music Box
Description: This strange music box only appears to be able to play a single tone. It was deposited at Windibank's two days before the black overcoat.

Name: Cat-Flapomat
Description: A compact machine for the rapid creation of small flaps in larger doors, to allow cats to come and go freely.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: While these ruffians were jostling with the broker, I was still near the entrance to the shop.

Person: Graydon

Person: Graydon

Person: Graydon

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Testimony 3 states: "The accused, in a black coat, shot the man in the back as he was trying to flee to safety!" by Graydon.

Evidence 4 ("White Cat Photograph #2 → Pawnbroker's Ticket (Coat)") is described as a redemption ticket with a bloody fingermark, which was later identified as Mr Mason's blood. This proves the black coat was pawned long before the murder and ties its provenance to an earlier case, implying Gina could not have been wearing it during the shooting (since she acquired it from the pawnbroker much later).

Therefore, Graydon's testimony that the "accused, in a black coat, shot the man" is contradicted by Evidence 4, which shows the coat was not in Gina's possession at the time of the shooting and that it was directly related to a prior incident.
